GE Weighs Selling Unit to Alstom

list-item.link: Heard on the Street: Deal Logic Lost in Translation

headline.main-hed: GE Considers Selling Train-Signal Business to Alstom
headline.deck: Move Could Bolster Appeal of GE's Bid for Alstom's Energy Unit

article-body.byline: By David Gauthier-Villars and Ted Mann

media.media-caption: General Electric plans to propose to Alstom that it choose between a direct purchase and a joint venture, people familiar with the matter said.

article-body.p: General Electric Co. is considering the sale of its train-signaling business to Alstom SA, in an effort to bolster the appeal of its $17 billion offer for the French engineering company's energy business and to counter German and Japanese suitors, according to people familiar with the matter.

Selling the signaling operations would help GE meet French President François Hollande's demand that the U.S. conglomerate help Alstom beef up its train business as a condition for blessing GE's purchase of one of France's industrial icons.

The two companies have held talks and agreed on a tentative value for GE's signaling unit, the people said. They declined to elaborate on that potential value, saying only that GE's business was slightly smaller than Alstom's, but more profitable.

With a direct sale, GE would go beyond its initial proposal—which Chief Executive Jeffrey Immelt outlined at a parliamentary hearing in France last month—to consider pooling its signaling operations with Alstom's in a joint venture.

list-item.link: Heard on the Street: Alstom Deal Logic Gets Lost in Translation

highlight.link: Siemens Moves to Derail GE Deal

list-item.link: At a Glance: The Alstom Takeover Saga

highlight.link: 'Made in France': GE's Latest Pitch in the Hunt for Alstom
Mitsubishi Heavy Seeks More Global Sway

article-body.p: When presenting a sweetened bid, possibly in the coming days, GE plans to propose to Alstom that it choose between a direct purchase and a joint venture, the people familiar with the matter said. Such a move would allow the maker of France's TGV bullet trains to decide whether it would rather conserve cash for other acquisitions or spend a chunk of it on buying GE's signaling unit.
The French government has expressed concerns that a slimmed-down Alstom, focused solely on the train business, would lack critical mass to compete globally.

A GE spokeswoman confirmed that Steve Bolze, chief executive of the company's power and water business, and John Flannery, its head of mergers and acquisitions, had met with French officials on Tuesday, and planned to remain in Paris as the company's talks with the government continue.
GE is battling a multipronged joint bid by Siemens AG of Germany and Mitsubishi Heavy Industries Ltd. of Japan to grab a large part of Alstom's assets.

media.media-caption: From left to right, General Electric Chief Executive Jeffrey Immelt, Alstom CEO Patrick Kron and Siemens CEO Joe Kaeser.

article-body.p: The U.S. company fired the opening shot in late April, offering to buy all of Alstom's energy assets, including its gas and steam turbines, wind mills and hydropower-equipment businesses.

The offer triggered a political furor in France, where the government said it wanted to have a say in the fate of the industrial giant, and invited interest from other potential bidders, including Siemens.

On Monday, Siemens and Mitsubishi Heavy presented an offer that the two companies said valued Alstom's power business at €14.2 billion ($19.3 billion). Under the plan, Siemens would buy the French company's gas-turbines business, while Mitsubishi Heavy would acquire minority stakes in a range of other Alstom operations.

In addition, Mitsubishi Heavy has offered to acquire a minority stake in Alstom and has said it "strongly" wished that the French government would also buy an interest in the company, alongside Mitsubishi.
Write to David Gauthier-Villars at David.Gauthier-Villars@wsj.com and Ted Mann at ted.mann@wsj.com
